action.action-desc: Mr. Neguse (for himself, Ms. Dexter, Ms. Stansbury, and Mr. Morelle) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure

form.official-title: To authorize transitional sheltering assistance for individuals who live in areas with unhealthy air quality caused by wildfires, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Wildfire Smoke Relief Act.

paragraph.header: Individual at risk of wildfire smoke related illness
paragraph.text: The term individual at risk of wildfire smoke related illness means an individual, living in an area where the air quality index is determined to be unhealthy for not less than 3 consecutive days as a result of a wildfire, who is—

subparagraph.text: a parent or guardian with a child who has not attained 19 years of age;
an individual who is 65 years of age or older;
an individual with chronic respiratory or cardiovascular illness; or
an individual with a chronic disease that is exacerbated by smoke inhalation.

paragraph.text: The term low-income individual means an individual from a family whose taxable income (as defined in section 63 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986) for the preceding year did not exceed 200 percent of an amount equal to the poverty level, as determined by using criteria of poverty established by the Bureau of Census.

subparagraph.text: a State or unit of local government;
a local public health authority; and

subsection.text: In carrying out the Transitional Sheltering Assistance Program of the Federal Emergency Management Agency under section 403 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act (42 U.S.C. 5170b), the President shall—

paragraph.text: provide assistance to a qualified entity to purchase and provide, to an individual at risk of wildfire smoke related illness, smoke-inhalation prevention equipment, including—

subparagraph.text: a face mask or respirator, such as—

clause.text: other equipment certified by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health to protect from airborne particle exposure;

subparagraph.text: low-cost equipment to keep smoke out of a house, such as:

clause.text: not more than 1 portable air-conditioning unit per household;
a screening and shading device; or

paragraph.text: in any case in which smoke-inhalation prevention equipment is not sufficient to mitigate the risk of illness, provide cost-efficient transitional shelter assistance to an individual at risk of wildfire smoke related illness.
